etymology.description: ideogrammic: 干 + 干 (“two trunks of equal height”); simplified from 開 (eliminating 門). In 開, 門 + 一 + 廾 depict hands unlatching a door.
etymology.interpretation: Two equal ‘trunks’ suggest parting or creating a gap, aligning with the notion of opening. The traditional form shows hands lifting a latch on a door, which naturally extends to meanings like open, start, and switch on.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 開 by removing the 門 ‘door’ enclosure and retaining the central element (combining 一 + 廾 as 开) to reduce strokes and complexity.

examples.chinese: 我们九点开会(我們九點開會)。
回家先开灯(回家先開燈)。
examples.english: Turn on the light when you get home.
